author: atroughton
title: atroughton published The UK National Comedy Party seizes power at Leicester Town Hall
text:
The UK National Comedy Party seizes power at Leicester Town Hall By atroughton | Posted: February 08, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Geoff Rowe addresses the council chamber at Leicester Town Hall The UK National Comedy Party seizes power at Leicester Town Hall X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
There has been a quiet revolution in the halls of power in Leicester. 
The UK National Comedy Party, led by Geoff Rowe, seized control of the city at Leicester Town Hall tonight. 
In a motion carried unanimously in the council chamber, the Comedy Party took over for the next 19 days. 
read more: Valentine's Day treat for pie-lovers produced by Melton bakers 
The crafty coup d'etat marked the launch of Leicester Comedy Festival, which runs until February 26. 
The motion was proposed by comedy actress Elaine Partling and seconded by deputy city mayor Councillor Rory Palmer. 
Rory Palmer addresses the gathering at the council chamber 
The motion stated that the UK National Comedy Party would reign for the next 19 days and guarantee everyone a jolly good time. 
Festival organiser Geoff said: "I have yet to kiss a baby, or be photographed in a factory or fiddle my expenses. However, in this world of Brexit, Farage, Trump, Clinton, May, Johnson and Crobyn, we reckon the UK needs a different kind of party â€“ an official comedy party. 
"There are plenty of comedians in positions of power, both nationally and internationally, so we thought we would join in. 
"I am very happy we now have a clear mandate to make everyone laugh, though we may not be quite as funny as some political leaders." 
Councillor Palmer said he fully supported the vote for the comedy party. 
He said: "This is one party that sees a sell-out as a good thing." 
After the vote, a bus took the victorious party members to the National Space Centre for the High Sheriff's Comedy Night. 
The night, compered by former National Space Centre worker turned professional comedian David Morgan, was in aid of the Warning Zone charity. 
Surinder Sharma, High Sheriff of Leicestershire , was present at the historic town hall vote. 
He said: "This is all good fun. "But the laughter will also enable us to raise money for the Warning Zone charity which helps children deal with the world." 
Leicester Comedy Festival started yesterday (WED) with Mark Watson and Richard Herring helping to kick off three weeks of events. 
The fun on day one included stand-up shows all over the city, beginning with a business breakfast at De Montfort University, where the festival began in 1994. 
Richard Herring's show was at The Cookie, in High Street, at 7pm, while Mock the Week panelist Mark Watson was due to be on at the same venue at 8pm. 
Other venues hosting events on the first day included Manhattan 34, The Exchange, Firebug and the National Space Centre. 
Between now and February 26 there will be more than 750 events, with performers including Jimmy Carr, Johnny Vegas, Ken Dodd, Stewart Lee, Sue Perkins, James Acaster and this year's Leicester Mercury Comedian of the Year, Tom Lucy.
